body:
Here is an example:
```
$ module avail paraview

------ /home/certik/repos/spack/share/spack/modules/linux-ubuntu16-x86_64 ------
paraview-5.0.0-gcc-5.4.0-chpcwgg paraview-5.0.0-gcc-5.4.0-ciwkkce
```
I would like to found out how these were built, so that I can figure out which one to load.

The best that I figured out is:
```
$ spack find -dlv paraview
==> 2 installed packages.
```

So the `chpcwgg` version is built with `+webkit`, and that's the one I want.

There is `spack load`, but that requires you to already know exactly how it was built, which of course I forget after a while (and also it's terribly slow due to #3318 and #3346).

Rather, I'd like to figure out using the hash how exactly the package was built. The above prints all the packages. Is it possible to only print information about this module: `paraview-5.0.0-gcc-5.4.0-chpcwgg`?

These alternatives do not work:
```
$ spack find -dlv paraview-5.0.0-gcc-5.4.0-chpcwgg
==> No package matches the query: paraview-5.0.0-gcc-5.4.0-chpcwgg
$ spack find -dlv chpcwgg
==> No package matches the query: chpcwgg
```
title: how to find information about a module
